description: From Latin comma, from Ancient Greek κόμμα (kómma), from κόπτω (kóptō, “I cut”).

entries.meaning: English Wikipedia has an article on:commaWikipedia (typography) The punctuation mark ⟨,⟩ used to indicate a set of parts of a sentence or between elements of a list.
examples: Synonyms: scratch comma, virgule, (in its obsolete form as a slash) virgula, (in its obsolete form as a middot) come, (obsolete) comma-point
Hyponyms: comma of Didymus, inverted comma, Oxford comma, serial comma, syntonic comma

entries.meaning: (Romanian typography) A similar-looking subscript diacritical mark.

(entomology) Any of various nymphalid butterflies of the genus Polygonia, having a comma-shaped white mark on the underwings, especially Polygonia c-album and Polygonia c-aureum of North Africa, Europe, and Asia.
(music) A difference in the calculation of nearly identical intervals by different ways.
(genetics) A delimiting marker between items in a genetic sequence.

(rhetoric) In Ancient Greek rhetoric, a short clause, something less than a colon, originally denoted by comma marks. In antiquity it was defined as a combination of words having no more than eight syllables in all. It was later applied to longer phrases, e.g. the Johannine comma.

verbs.description: comma (third-person singular simple present commas, present participle commaing, simple past and past participle commaed)

entries.meaning: (rare, transitive) To place a comma or commas within text; to follow, precede, or surround a portion of text with commas.
